results.title: David Anderson: works on film
results.creator_credit: David Anderson, David Jeffcock, Barnaby Spurrier, James Bradley and Redwing
results.brief_description: David Anderson is one of the Uk’s leading animators, and in this collection his creative and technical range is given full rein. The program begins with Anderson’s BAFTA Award-winning debut film “Dreamland express” (1982) which captures the rich fantasy life of childhood. “Sweet disaster, dreamless sleep” (1986) is a poignant allegory on the theme of the nuclear nightmare. “Deadtime stories for big folk” is the title of a collaboration between Anderson and the novelist Russell Hoban, and a documentary on this includes the full versions of the two films involved, “Deadsy” (1989) and “Door” (1990). Both have won many awards and are powerful and disturbing pieces.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Anderson, David Jeffcock, Barnaby Spurrier, James Bradley and Redwing

results.title: David
results.creator_credit: Steve Mason and Religious Film Society
results.brief_description: David Ellis, a 19 year old physically and mentally handicapped person, shares his relationship to everyday situations. The effect of his disability on family and personal relationships. A strongly religious film.
results.description: David Ellis, a 19 year old physically and mentally handicapped person, shares his relationship to everyday situations. The effect of his disability on family and personal relationships. A strongly religious film.

results.title: Orphee et Eurydice
results.creator_credit: Peter Butler, Stefanos Lazaridis, Australian Broadcasting Corporation and Opera Australia
results.brief_description: Orphee et Eurydice, directed by Stefanos Lazaridis, music by Christoph Willibald Gluck, libretto by Ranierie da Calzabigi, and adapted for the French performing edition by Pierre-Louis Moline, tells the tale of lovers separated by death. Orphee must go on a quest to Hades to find his dead wife Eurydice and bring her back to the living. The voyage is full of peril, and it is only after much heartache that he is reunited with his own true love. Features singers David Hobson (Orphee), Miriam Gormley (L’Amour), Amanda Thane (Eurydice), and The Australian Opera Chorus. Also features the Dancers of the Meryl Tankard Australian Dance Theatre and Dancers of The Australian Opera choreographed by Meryl Tankard, and The Australian Opera and Ballet Orchestra conducted by Marco Guidarini. Recorded live at the Sydney Opera House on 20 September 1993 and produced for television in association with the Australian Broadcasting Corporation. Sung in French with English subtitles.

results.title: Organelles in living plant cells
results.brief_description: Shows the appearance and behaviour of all organelles that can be resolved by the phase and dark-field microscope, such as nuclei, chloroplasts, golgi bodies and kinoplasm. Discloses the interactions between the organelles and cytoplasmic network. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: Daughters of the dust [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Julie Dash, American Playhouse Theatrical Films, Geechee Girls Production and WMG
results.brief_description: At the turn of the century the Peazant family, a multigenerational community threatened with break-up, gathers for a reunion on an island off the coast of South Carolina, historically a place of entry for the European slave ships and a haven for self-emancipated Africans and indigenous peoples. Structured around the twin narratives of Nana, born into slavery, and that of the Unborn Child, this is a rites-of-passage story invoking Islam, Christianity and West African spiritual customs. It is not narrative-driven in the Western mode but is balletic, operatic, non-linear and based on the African oral tradition of the Griot (story-teller), drawing on the Gullah dialect. Dash was also inspired by the literature of African-American women writers. Cast includes Adisa Anderson, Cora Lee Day, Alva Rogers, Barbara-0 and Trula Hoosier.

results.title: Ordinary people
results.creator_credit: Doug Miles and University of Pittsburgh
results.brief_description: Demonstrates the symptoms and dynamics of child abuse showing how relatively normal, average parents with high stress levels and unrealistic child rearing expectations can become abusive parents.

results.title: Orchestra!
results.creator_credit: Declan Lowney, Jonathan Hewes and Initial (GB)
results.brief_description: This series is an entertaining and informative introduction to the symphony orchestra. Featuring Maestro George Solti and the musical talent and humour of Dudley Moore, the three volumes trace the development of the various sections of the orchestra from the time of Bach and Handel to today. The theme of the four parts of the orchestra is established by breaking down a piece of music into its four constituent parts - strings, brass, percussion and woodwind.

results.title: The Making of 'Orchestra!': Piano. The conductor
results.creator_credit: Declan Lowney, Jonathan Lewes and Initial (GB)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Orchestra!”.
This volume of the “Orchestra!” series explores the making of the series. It examines the role of the piano as a solo instrument within an orchestra and the role of the conductor from learning the score through interpretation, the metronome and rehearsal technique.

results.title: Opus: impressions of British art and culture
results.creator_credit: Don Levy, James Archibald and British Information Services
results.brief_description: An impressionistic survey of the arts in Britain ranging from sculptors and painters at work to a display of Mary Quant fashions and vistas of modern architecture. The theatre is represented by excerpts from three plays staged by the Royal Shakespeare Company and there is a sequence from a new ballet by Sir Frederick Ashton. Some of the work of Henry Moore is seen as well as paintings by Francis Bacon. Includes a brief appearance by a very young Googie Withers.
results.title_for_label: Opus: impressions of British art and culture
results.creator_credit_for_label: Don Levy, James Archibald and British Information Services
